Should you play this game ? Is this the best total war to choose ? The answer is yes.
I’ve been asking myself the same question 2 months ago, as I wanted to play a new total war (last one was probably Attila and Warhammer 2).
And thanks god I made this choice.
This the most refined total war game out there and clearly hundred time better than Warhammer III that is receiving plenty of DLCs. I love fantasy, and I also tried WHIII, but this game is overrated, and I was deeply disappointed. Any player that ever touched Three Kingdoms can tell: this is pure diamond.

You may hesitate since it’s ancient China and you may not be familiar with this era. I was totally ignorant about this period, and I was so into the game that I started to be interested to the lore (it’s so cool).

GOOD POINTS

First, this game is beautiful, in many ways:
-	Interface is great
-	Construction buildings look cool when you click a commandery 
-	Character artworks are very nice 
-	Map looks awesome, there are a lot of visual and sound details when you zoom in
-	Battles look so great, nice screenshots to take 

Second point, there are plenty of interesting mechanics:
-	Many faction leaders have special buildings, capacities, attributes and units that can be very cool, unique, and enjoyable, making every game different in its own way
-	Despite some weird and rare cases, diplomacy is overall very nice, lot of possibilities, and AI is doing fine 
-	Characters have a LOT of distinct attributes that affect their administrative, battle and campaign skills, so there are plenty of possibilities (Stats, capacity tree, items, traits, roles)
-	To complete the previous point, you can even give special titles to your characters, which is very cool and boost them as well (example: General who gives tranquillity to the north, orator, etc). 
-	Court, relationships and administration is interesting, and scales as you rank up. At some point, you can regularly choose special events/boost for your faction.
-	There is a spy system that is cool and give plenty of possibilities (such as your spy becoming the faction leader of the faction he was sent in)
-	Research tree is fine and allow a lot of different possible choices that are decent
-	Your goal is to be emperor. If the original emperor is still governing, an additional imperial system exists and affect slightly your faction (ex: you can be marked as imperial enemy by the emperor)
-	 Food and money are balanced and never seemed frustrating
-	There are actually a ton of little mechanics that are cool, but I won’t detail it here (resources, assignments, seasons, faction leader tendencies in diplomacy, satisfaction, xp and weapon, rank scaling possibilities, unique features, etc)

There are a lot of things to consider, and even with +300h I’m pretty sure I’m missing some stuff to optimize everything. It can be overwhelming at start but keep it up and you will have a blast.

 About battles: 
-	Best battles in the entire franchise in term of gameplay
-	Units are reactive, the interface is easy to understand and managing unit is pleasant
-	Units are not randomly stopping to do what you asked them (it happens for me in WHIII and ruin the game really)
-	You can burn stuff like forest, and can be game breaker
-	Generals are cool as they have special abilities, and if you don’t like this kind of gameplay, you can just change the game mode, so your general is just a unit as in total war Attila (and other historical title I believe) 
-	I said it already, but it’s so good looking

About units:
-	There are some very cool units, with some elite units that are unlocked by research (every branch has its specialized unit), or by being emperor for example



CRITICS

Visually:
-	If you get interested in this era, you will notice that non-principal characters lack a bit of diversity, which can be disappointing 

Mechanics:
-	As always for many games, mechanics could be improved, more complex, more in depth (research tree, spy, court, events etc)
-	Both campaign and battle difficulty are not really how smart an AI is, but rather how cheated he is, which is sad. Instead of fighting a smarter enemy, you fight a dude with boosted statistics (battle) or biased against you for some mysterious reasons (diplomacy). Also, AI are kind of ignoring diplomatic maluses, and can be best friend easily with other factions compared to you (at least in higher difficulties)
-	Spy system could be improved to be more complete on some little points
-	A lot of things are not really explained and you kind of discover them at some point randomly (can be a good point in a way)

About units:
-	Even if there are cool units, there are not that much different units compared to what could be done, and that can make different campaigns feel repetitive on this point


GOOD NEWS

All these critics ? Can be fixed.
Indeed, I highly recommend using a modpack called TROM+TUP (there are also other mudpack that are great for this).
This mod will introduce new art for secondary characters, add some other characters, increases mechanics in the game (skill tree, attributes, etc), allow a better control on the game, and most important, it adds many units that are VERY COOL and different, with a unique recruitment system. Playing base game and playing with this mod are both cool, but clearly this modpack increases significantly the play time, making you re-discover the game. Strongly recommend trying it out after some vanilla campaigns.

Anyway, this is the coolest total war in the last years, it feels still pretty recent even if he was released 6 years ago. And I think it is way more fun and pleasant to play compared to Warhammer III. As long as a new historical big title is not out, this game is clearly the best you can play

Ahhh What can I say about TWTK aka Total War Three Kingdoms other than hot dam it's amazing... For a 7 out of 10 game here's why.

Total War Three Kingdoms is based on one of the most romanticized points of history in the world, China's Three Kingdoms era starting from the Yellow Turbans all the way all the way to the Jin dynasty princes. It is loaded with tons of characters that if you love the novel, historical records, or the hit franchise dynasty warriors you'll notice tons of names and faces. Mechanics out the whazoo, it's truly astonishing that the devs created so many characters and factions, leaders don't play the same having different agendas, personalities, starting positions, and more. Cao Cao doesn't play like Liu Bei, and Liu Bei is dramatically different from Sun Ce, Yuan Shu, Yuan Shao, Kong Rong, and many others you can pick to play as. In TWTK you are given so many choices it might seem overwhelming at first, to who you pick, how you play, and what game type you'd like to play on being Romance or Records, Romance follows the novels where generals were literally superhuman heroes on the battlefield who can take out a quarter of armies by themselves, while records follows a more realistic style where one man cannot kill 1000 by himself it takes on a more tactical approach to the gameplay instead. There's so much more that if I tried listing all of the good things about the game this review would be way to long, instead i'll go over the DLC, why it isn't perfect, and what makes it near perfect but why that dampens it's score for me.

The DLCs are pretty good they add a lot more to the game and a few spins on the gameplay loop if you play as one of the DLC factions being the Yellow Turbans from Mandate of Heaven 182 AD Furious Wilds being the awesome Nanman of the south a bunch of tribal people riding elephants and tigers, Fate Divided and World Betrayed are good ones as well adding a few good characters to the roster, plus the free leaders. The game has no lack for content my score says around 40 or 50 but I play it offline and have around 400 hours into the game. Which is why I can say it isn't perfect a few characters are missing from the vanilla rosters ones you'd think would have been amongst the first to be developed like Lu Meng wasn't in vanilla, neither was Lianshi, Zuo Ci, the Jin Kingdom besides Sima Yi is absent in vanilla. The team never got around to making unique art and characters for all of the characters in game. How is this fixed you ask? Mods.

The Modding scene has the be one of the greatest ones I've ever seen filling in the gaps the developers couldn't do before no longer supporting the game. Adding characters, overhauls to gameplay, new graphics, scripts, even adding areas to the map to add Korea, yeah it gets that wild. However, because of this I give the game a 7 out of 10 although I love it like a 10 out of 10 but, those mods were only made because the vanilla lacked in some places. Be that as it is I still recommend people buy this game and try it as it is worth the time.

Started my first campaign, got to around turn 90
The game consistently crashes during an AI player turn; nothing I do seems to change that, so my campaign is now locked.
Multiple players seem to have reported this, but there is no official solution.

EDIT:
I managed to finish a campaign, but the game still crashed quite frequently.
Overall, I found it less enjoyable than other TW installments;
The reforms (3Kingdoms research tree) feel quite slow, and because they are locked to a 5 turn cooldown, with no way to reduce that interval, makes it impossible to go through the whole lot of them in a normal game.
The combat is ok, but most units in the game are militias, with only mid-to-late upgrades improving this. This means morale is a major issue. Also, most garrisons are garbage, 3 heroes could single-handedly beat any default garrison in the game.
Diplomacy feels overly complicated; there are lots of options that are never available (?) and many options that are never agreed on by the AI.
Buildings again feel more complicated than usual; there are 3 buildings in every of the five categories available to major cities, but many do not really feel useful. I ended up building about the same 5 things in all my cities. Also the main building going from lvl 1 to lvl 10 feels exaggerated; not to mention the food cost for such a city is insane; that means that having more than a couple of those is simply not feasible(also pointless, since the benefits are not really worth it).
The character skill tree is very ambiguous, and since it is designed like a grid, it is very hard to specialize people on combat or economy; most often I found myself picking traits I had no need of because nothing else was available that interested me.
There is also a spy system? while I understand the idea, it felt clunky, and more trouble than it was worth. Rarely did I get something useful out of it, and by the end I abandoned it completely.
The graphics look nice, but my god combat in forests is horrendous, They are so well done you can't actually see a thing in them. Good luck trying to see that flanking cavalry. Oh, also, if you use fire ammo, you will set the forest around you on fire, which will kill your units.

Better buy a TW game that actually lets you play the campaign and have fun while doing it.

Game fulfills a strong niche as an interesting take on the Three Kingdoms era, a historical chinese approach from a major western developer. It has a Total War gameplay that has an unique approach compared with other Total War - choosing to focus on flashy duels, a harder approach to alliances & theming unit and items which are somewhat fun but pretty flawed as they often limit your playstyle in unnatural ways. If you are like me. you'd have much more fun collecting people/ rare items, thanks to more RPG vibe this game has.

It shares several similarities with the recent Total War titles such as Troy and Total War Warhammer series by focusing on legendary lords with very unique faction effects akin to a Civilization game. So if you enjoyed those, you might enjoy this one as well.

I would like to point out a difference to Romance from the Three Kingdoms from KOEI, a very different kind of game in the same theme and shares the 'narrative focus' that this title does. For the most part, this game tries to give you narrative branches but due to unpredictable AI and RNG and lack of flags to put you back on track - you have lesser control over it if your purpose is try to follow the narrative. So don't be surprised if Lu Bu simply just dies by accident. This game allows you to form relationships (similar to ROTK13 with expansion) but it does put a cap. So you can't befriend as many people as you'd like - the weakest relationship simply disappear as if they never existed.

And yet, the main criticism of this game is that its development was cut short and there's still more technical issues with this game that you would have to be wary of - and use community fixes to have a more playable experience.

Eg. If you are a Singleplayer player, the game is mostly playable. But some factions still have issues with their faction mechanics/UI. For cooperative players, the engine bugs can crash the game for various reasons, such as having too many units. I was just fielding a full stack to fight two stacks - woe on me.

On the side note, AI in the same province as you can detect your presence quite reliably - so it complicates your ability to form ambushes and catch them unguarded if you don't plan around that. This game has quite a few oddities like this, so be careful.

You'd probably be fine if you are just Liu Bei-ing or Cao Cao-ing in Singleplayer.

In respect to the developer's developmental ethos since dropping this game, I would still have to give this a cautious negative review. Play at your own risk, but do enjoy the game as-is.

Game fulfills a strong niche as an interesting take on the Three Kingdoms era, a historical chinese approach from a major western developer. It has a Total War gameplay that has an unique approach compared with other Total War - choosing to focus on flashy duels, a harder approach to alliances & theming unit and items which are somewhat fun but pretty flawed as they often limit your playstyle in unnatural ways. If you are like me. you'd have much more fun collecting people/ rare items, thanks to more RPG vibe this game has.

It shares several similarities with the recent Total War titles such as Troy and Total War Warhammer series by focusing on legendary lords with very unique faction effects akin to a Civilization game. So if you enjoyed those, you might enjoy this one as well.

I would like to point out a difference to Romance from the Three Kingdoms from KOEI, a very different kind of game in the same theme and shares the 'narrative focus' that this title does. For the most part, this game tries to give you narrative branches but due to unpredictable AI and RNG and lack of flags to put you back on track - you have lesser control over it if your purpose is try to follow the narrative. So don't be surprised if Lu Bu simply just dies by accident. This game allows you to form relationships (similar to ROTK13 with expansion) but it does put a cap. So you can't befriend as many people as you'd like - the weakest relationship simply disappear as if they never existed.

And yet, the main criticism of this game is that its development was cut short and there's still more technical issues with this game that you would have to be wary of - and use community fixes to have a more playable experience.

Eg. If you are a Singleplayer player, the game is mostly playable. But some factions still have issues with their faction mechanics/UI. For cooperative players, the engine bugs can crash the game for various reasons, such as having too many units. I was just fielding a full stack to fight two stacks - woe on me.

On the side note, AI in the same province as you can detect your presence quite reliably - so it complicates your ability to form ambushes and catch them unguarded if you don't plan around that. This game has quite a few oddities like this, so be careful.

You'd probably be fine if you are just Liu Bei-ing or Cao Cao-ing in Singleplayer.

In respect to the developer's developmental ethos since dropping this game, I would still have to give this a cautious negative review. Play at your own risk, but do enjoy the game as-is.
